title: Simple Cipher
problem_statement:
Simple Cipher

Given an encrypted string consisting of English letters, decrypt the string by replacing each character with the character that is k positions away on the alphabet. Counter-clockwise from A to Z is considered. For example, if k = 2, then:

  • Encrypted \'Y\' returns \'W\';
  • Encrypted \'R\' returns \'P\';
  • And so on. The decrypted string is \'TRAME\'.

Input Format

The function accepts the following parameters:

  • string encrypted: the string to decrypt
  • int k: the position of the character to find

Output Format

Returns the decrypted string.

Constraints

  • The length of the string will be between 1 and 100.
  • All characters in the string are uppercase English letters.
  • 1 ≤ k ≤ 25

Examples

Input:
YTAOG
2
Output:
TRAME

The string \'YTAOG\' is decrypted by shifting each character 2 positions back in the alphabet.

title: Relative Ratings
problem_statement:
Relative Ratings

One of the games launched on Amazon has come up with a unique rating system for the players. It is based on their relative skill levels and absolute ratings.

There are n players where the ith player has a skill level of skill[i] and an absolute rating of rating[i].

Given skill, rating, and k, find each player\'s relative rating.

Input Format

The function getRelativeRatings takes the following arguments:

  • vector skill: The skills of the players
  • vector rating: The absolute rating of the players
  • int k: The number of top skills to consider for relative rating

Output Format

Returns long int[n]: The relative ratings of the players.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ n ≤ 2 * 10^5
  • 0 < k < n - 1
  • 1 ≤ skill[i] ≤ 10^9
  • 1 ≤ rating[i] ≤ 10^9

Examples

Input:
4
skill = [4, 5, 9, 7]
rating = [1, 2, 3, 4]
k = 2
Output:
0
1
6
3

The optimal skills to consider are [], [5, 7], and [4, 5]. The relative ratings are 0, 1, 2, and 1 + 2 = 3.
